text: Yeah, thank you, Daniel.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And thanks to those of you that are attending online.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So my name is Josh Bongard.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'm a professor of computer science here at the University of Vermont.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And my bread and butter in my lab is the study of robotics and AI.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And obviously, we're in the middle of the current AI summer.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So what I wanted to do today is show a couple of highlights from my group, things that I've worked on in the past and that we're working on at the moment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that I hope in the long term will help us realize sort of the long-term vision for a lot of those trying to create intelligent machines, which is to create machines that are helpful but also safe.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're part of the way there, but as anyone who's worked with chat GPT or stable diffusion knows or even has a robot vacuum cleaner at home, there are some limitations to our current technology.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's hard to create machines that are autonomous,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and useful and safe all simultaneously.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So what are the things that we're missing?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's what I wanted to sort of seed the pool with today and hopefully we can move on to an interactive discussion about it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I'm gonna leave this slide up and just sort of talk over the slide for a few minutes that'll hopefully generate some food for thought and then questions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is a snapshot from some of the projects I've worked on over the years.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: First thing you'll probably notice is there's a lot of different robots that have very different structural properties.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They not only act differently, but look very different.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that is a fundamental foundation in everything we do in my research group, which is to try and understand how the body facilitates cognition.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Years ago with my PhD advisor, we wrote a popular science book called How the Body Shapes the Way We Think.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we can mean that literally or figuratively.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We wrote that book a while ago.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We made some arguments about how the body shapes the way we think.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And since that time, my group and others have formulated other arguments for why or how the body shapes the way we think.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I'm hoping to survey some of those today.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As I mentioned, you can see a lot of different robots here, very different structure.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They've got very different form and function, but across each of the pair of videos that you see here, you'll notice that there's also a common pattern, which is on the left side, you tend to see something that's virtual, and on the right side of the video pair, you tend to see something that's physical.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this illustrates the basic approach that my group takes to understanding how the body shapes the way we think.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: which is to create AI that creates robots, creates embodied AI.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So what do I mean by that?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What I mean is that in all of the projects that you see here, we create an AI that searches the space of all possible robots,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that could solve the tasks that we want the robots to solve.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Most people that are familiar with AI and robotics and autonomous cars and drones have a rough understanding that AI is somehow optimizing or tuning the brain of the autonomous car or the drone or the robot, what have you.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's an underlying assumption in all of that current, in most current robotics, which is that the AI tunes the brain, but does not tune the body.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Tesla cars are dreamed up mostly by humans and an AI tunes their brain or their control policy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But of course nature doesn't work that way.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Nature produced us and all the other intelligent organisms on this planet by carefully tuning body and brain simultaneously.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Certain bodies facilitate certain kinds of behaviors and certain kinds of intelligent behavior and other bodies don't.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They obstruct that particular behavior or that intelligent behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So in all of our work, we ask the AI not just to tune the brain of a robot, but its body simultaneously.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And as you can see visually here, the AI often comes up with bodies that are well suited to whatever we want them to do.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So if you direct your attention to the very top left of the screen for a moment, this is now a 22 year old experiment, but I think it still visualizes the potential of this approach.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In this case, we were interested in creating a robot that can brachiate, that can swing across beams or tree branches or electrical wires for various inspection tasks.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you'll notice that in this case, the AI came up with a solution that in retrospect seems intuitive.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The robot has to carry a very heavy battery, which you can see in the physical robot in the top left there, the black box that's at the bottom.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the AI has figured out how to design the body of this robot so that it's actually able to exploit the forward momentum of this heavy object, this battery, to facilitate its movement or brachiation across this physical beam.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it's a simple example, a simple robot, a simple task, but it demonstrates this interplay between AI, robotics, body, and brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If the AI was not free to place the battery at a particular place on the robot's body, it would be much harder, it would require more energy, it would require a more complex brain for the robot to figure out how to move its heavy weight across this beam.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that idea of tuning body and brain has suffused everything that we work on.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Some other examples you can see in the top center and the top right.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Here we have a robot that suffers damage.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Its body changes over time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So now the AI has to grapple with not just designing a body,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: but grappling with a body that changes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One of the things that we as intelligent organisms here in the world and all embodied AI, all autonomous cars, all drones, all robots have to deal with is entropy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The world throws a lot of stuff at us.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We have to deal with wear and tear, injury,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In our case, we grow from a single cell into about 10 to the 12 cells.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We change massively in terms of our physical magnitude.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: How do you continue to operate, keep yourself alive and do whatever it is you need to do across massive morphological change?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That is not an easy thing to do.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And again, it requires an AI.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If it's going to do this with robots, it's got to figure out how to carefully tune body and brain to deal
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: with the generation of behavior inside a body that is changing either unexpectedly due to injury and wear and tear or intentionally.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You can see in the very center panel, this is again a pretty good visualization of where designing body along with brain comes in handy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If we want to make flying machines or swimming machines,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We have to very, very carefully tune the geometry and material properties of the body itself to realize flight.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So what you're seeing in this middle panel here, this is partway through the AI experimenting with the design of different kinds of wings for an ornithopter, a drone that flies by flapping its wings.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This flexible wing that you see here in the center of the screen, this is a bit of a transition from traditional robots that are made of rigid structures, like you can see in the top row,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: into a more modern era in robotics, which is sometimes referred to as soft robotics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Material science has come a long way in the last 20 years.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we can now start to build robots, embodied AI.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can start to build robots out of materials other than rigid plastic and metals.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we can, again, we can start to move into an era in which robots, like organisms, can exploit the material properties of their bodies to facilitate whatever behaviors they need to do to survive or be useful to humans and so on.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So in the middle right panel, this is a highlight of some work that my group has done in collaboration with Rebecca Kramer Bottiglio's lab at Yale.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Rebecca's lab is famously advancing the state of the art in soft robotics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What can you get robots to do when they're made out of soft materials?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You can see an example of some of those soft robots, middle right, and a very different soft robot lower left.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: which is exploiting its body properties in order to move in interesting ways one of the interesting things about soft robotics in my perspective is that it starts to usher in an era in which
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: robots can actually grow and complexify their bodies.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You can see these hollow cubes in the middle right and these hollow sort of chambers in the bottom left expanding and contracting as we push and pull air into and then out of the body of the robot.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Suddenly, now you have robots that can change their geometry, they can change their volume,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: they become what's known as thermodynamically open.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's a fancy term for meaning that they can draw new material and new energy into themselves.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The thermodynamically open machines that you see middle right and lower left, the only
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: thing they're drawing into their body is more air but it's a start i mentioned already that humans grow from a single cell into 10 to the 12 cells every organism on this planet with a few exceptions starts small and gets bigger over its lifetime that fundamental morphological change start small start simple and gradually grow in size and complexity
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that provides scaffolding.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It provides a gradient on which to learn how to gradually grapple with the world around you.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Most organisms, again, there are exceptions, are not thrust into this world with all of their machinery online from the beginning.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Just the way I'm phrasing this is obviously intentional to sort of dichotomize growing organisms and robots with fixed bodies.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: autonomous cars are still very dangerous.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Autonomous drones are still very dangerous to be around because
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: 99.99% of the time they do the right thing, but every once in a while they don't know what to do and no one knows what they're going to do in those uncertain circumstances.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That is a very concerning situation as we start to now deploy robots and autonomous vehicles into everyday environments where they are in close proximity to humans.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Why is it that even with state of the art AI and with all of Google's data centers and AI training algorithms, we still can't rub out that 0.001% where no one knows what's going to happen.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Part of the reason, again, is these machines are born with complex bodies.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We drop a controller into
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: a one-ton autonomous car made of metal and plastics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's very dangerous.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We don't grow autonomous cars from a very small, simple, lightweight machine that can't cause anyone any harm whatsoever.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then when that simple, small machine demonstrates and verifies to us that it's safe, then we allow it to become larger and more complex.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It sounds like silly sci-fi.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Why would we build a machine like that?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But again, every organism starts simple and grows in complexity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And if it doesn't do the right thing, if it performs dangerous actions that are harmful to itself or fatal to itself, by definition, it doesn't get any further.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's again, one of the ways of thinking about how the body shapes the way we think.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In my personal and professional opinion, any physical machines that we deploy into the real world, they should start as very small, lightweight machines that can't harm anyone.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They have a very limited number of actions that they can perform and they sort of cycle through all those actions and verify everything.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And only then can they take
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: more mass, more energy into themselves?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Can they recruit more material?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They can sort of be allowed to be thermodynamically open and grow and complexify themselves.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's lots of ways in which we're starting to create machines that grow and complexify themselves.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I just talked about these soft robots that can pull in air or possibly fluids.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They could be hydrodynamic machines.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They could mechanically or magnetically connect to other robots that sort of swarm robotics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's another path to growing machines.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: At the moment, most of these machines are still restricted to academic labs.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They also are not safe yet, but I think in the long run, they're going to be a safer alternative to dropping AI into very large, complex, heavy, dangerous machines and crossing our fingers and hoping for the best.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Okay, so I've talked a little bit about rigid robots and soft robots.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I wanna try and talk as little as possible, so there's some time for a good discussion, but I wanna talk about what I see as sort of a third era of robotics and embodied AI, which is just starting to open up in the last few years, which is biobotics or creating biobots.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you can see two biobots on display at the bottom center of my slide here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: A biobot is a robot that's made up of only biological components, no technological components whatsoever.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So in the bottom left here, Kriegman, Blackist and Levin and myself in 2020 published a paper demonstrating the first biobot.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This became known after publication in the popular media as xenobots, X-E-N-O, xeno, xenobots.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: because these xenobots are built from about 2,000 frog cells, and the cells were taken from a particular species of frog, which is Xenopus laevis.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Michael Levin, our biology colleague at Tufts University, is world renowned for demonstrating that you can reconfigure genetically unmodified materials, like, for example, frog cells,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that rearrangement of living tissues not only does not kill the organism, the organism is able to, in some cases, continue on doing what it does, what it needs to do, ingest materials, survive, reproduce in this reconfigured state.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's a lot of biological implications for that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One of the biological implications is that frog DNA does not code for frog.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What you're looking at in the bottom left, the xenobot, is about a millimeter in diameter, so it looks like a speck of pepper to the unmagnified eye, and yet it's able to walk around the bottom of a petri dish.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It doesn't have all the features of a living organism, but it's got enough of them that it's motile.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's able to get itself from point A to point B.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So one of the other implications for AI of this biological discovery that you could rearrange genetically unmodified living tissues is that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: maybe we can task an AI with discovering novel rearrangements of living tissue to produce robots, to produce something that moves around and does something useful on a human's behalf.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that's what I mean by a biobot, a biobot that's made from, in this case, genetically unmodified cells.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: um the the swarm of xenobots that you see in the bottom uh right uh as you can see they're sort of pushing around some material in their their dish this um sort of visually hints at applications for this this type of robotic technology which is they might be able to act like very very small roomba
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: robot vacuum cleaners in the future.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They might be able to collect microplastics out of waterways or cancer cells out of bloodstreams.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The swarm that you see that's cleaning up in this slide at the bottom right, the material that they're cleaning up is actually other frog cells.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It turns out that if the AI designs this swarm just right, and the swarm that you're looking at, this is an AI-designed swarm.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The AI came up with the shape for each member of the swarm.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The swarm is pushing these little white circles, which are individual frog cells, pushing them into piles.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Turns out these individual frog skin cells at a certain stage of development are sticky.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and they clump together into a pile.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And some of these piles, if they're big enough, if they contain enough frog cells, they will grow very small hairs on the surface cells, the cells that are on the surface of the pile.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And those little small hairs are called cilia.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They're usually used to pull dirt and pathogens off the body of frogs.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Here, when those cilia grow on small piles of frog cells, they're able to exert enough force against the surrounding water that these piles start to move.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so what you have in essence is a child xenobot.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This swarm pushes cells together and in essence makes copies of themselves.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is another implication of this work is that in this case, the AI has figured out how to design robots.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that replicate, they make copies of themselves by finding raw material in their environment and constructing copies of themselves.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This has been a longstanding dream in robotics, dating back a very long time to John von Neumann in the 1950s, who had a thought experiment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It would be great if we could create robots that would create copies of themselves, which would create copies of themselves,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And if those robots do useful work for humans as a side effect, for von Neumann that was creating moon bases and then Mars bases and then colonizing the galaxy, which sounds great.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But the seed of this idea is if we want robots to really be useful at scale,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Instead of manually constructing billions of robots and then deploying them to do something useful, which is expensive, it would be much cheaper to make one robot that does something useful for us.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And by the way, it also makes two copies of itself, which does more useful work for us and four and eight and 16 and so on.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're not there yet with the xenobots, but it's a demonstration that that is possible.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And again, all of that becomes possible because the AI is designing both the bodies and the brains of these robots.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is very far now from the traditional view of AI and robotics, where we build a robot body, we humans build a robot body, and then the AI tinkers with the brain of that fixed machine.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Part of the reason why I'm here today and part of the message of my group is we need to think more broadly about how to combine AI and robotics and possibly synthetic biology.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And when we do, when we think more broadly, there are whole new paths that open up to ways in which we might create in the future, not yet, but in the future, create intelligent, useful and safe machines.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In the current era in AI, there is one particular approach, which is auto completion of tokens, which has come to dominate the field and come to dominate the popular imagination.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We all kind of have an understanding more or less of what ChatGPT is doing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And there are some very strong lobbying organizations out there that are bent on convincing us that if we just do this with more compute, more data,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We will eventually get to safe machines.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: My contention is there just isn't enough data out there to make non embodied AI like chat GPT and stable diffusion and all the rest to make them safe.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We have to think differently about designing bodies and brains of machines simultaneously to realize this long term goal.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: My first question is, how over these 22 years, how have the materials, the theories, like the contexts, advances in Turing computation, all these kinds of things, how have they intersected and just what has the ride been like as you pursued these questions?

text: you bought some wires and you wired everything up.
